summary: 10-year-old Chihiro (Daveigh Chase) moves with her parents to a new home in the Japanese countryside. After taking a wrong turn down a wooded path, Chihiro and her parents discover an amusement park with a stall containing an assortment of food. To her surprise, Chihiro's parents begin eating and then transform into pigs. In this supernatural realm, Chihiro encounters a host of characters and endures labor in a bathhouse for spirits, awaiting a reunion with her parents.

If you'd choose to ever see only one animated movie, this is it: Studio Ghibli's "Spirited Away" will prove it's boundless merits to you, starting with it's breathtaking, hand drawn presentation. Thru incredibly patient detail, Ghibli's artists bring to life everything from accurately portraying the feelings and physical movement of a young girl, to landscapes and environments full of detail that are so typical of the respect given by Japanese Shinto. But more importantly, the story in "Spirited Away" addresses the hallmark issues of modern Japan; issues which are incredibly human, and universal.

A coming of age story, this animated movie brings to light almost all the important challenges that we face today: Everything from bravery in the face of disaster, the value of generosity and friendship, respect and patience for others... I continue to draw inspiration and see depth in this film years after having first seen it. 

Japanese culture is known to be one of hard work and excellence, and "Spirited Away" presents that solitary, dedicated life to a tee. Another great theme in Japanese culture is the important ability to befriend enemies and adapt to change. But perhaps it's greatest insight: that whatever you have lived, no matter if forgotten, stays with you and empowers you, is perhaps this movie's most important lesson. One that is transmitted with the greatest care and consideration; something that is deeply lacking in our society today.

"Spirited Away" is a shining example of excellence in story telling, and will stand as a benchmark for filmmakers for ages to come.

This will be my last review for 2022. Where do I even begin? If I ever did a Top 10 list with the greatest films I have ever seen, Spirited Away would easily be in the top 5. It is, undoubtedly, one of the greatest Japanese films I've seen, one of the greatest animated films, and certainly of the greatest films I have ever seen in my life. Probably one of the best of all time, as well. In contrast to Pixar and Disney, who already suffer from sequel/spinoff fatigue, repetitive themes and familiar plots (that elicit the same feelings all the time), Studio Ghibli manages to create true experiences. I don't mean to blame Pixar or Disney (they are both excellent in their own right), but movies from Studio Ghibli always make me feel something, whether that is happiness, sadness, awe, fear, melancholy, anger. Their animation is beautiful, absolutely gorgeous eye candy. Their characters (mostly female heroines) are always fleshed out and well developed. The plotlines are stupidly profound and engaging. The themes they present are relevant and thought provoking. I almost don't want to watch them, because I'm overcome with sadness when I realize that the beautiful adventure I witness will be over soon. Studio Ghibli are special. Their works communicate with the viewer, they make the strongest viewers (of every age, that is) sentimental, they make you feel like a child. They make you proud to still enjoy animation. They are timeless masterpieces. And Japanese cinema overall (along with Italian) is the only one that makes me so emotional. As for the movie itself, I cannot say much, because this is an experience that shouldn't be spoiled. The animation is astonishing, the characters lovely (I absolutely adore Kamaji and I would die for him), the story intriguing, Chihiro herself is a perfect protagonist because of her imperfections. Needless to say that the soundtrack created by auteur Joe Hisaishi is wonderful (I love his works very much and I consider him equal to John Williams). Hayao Miyiazaki himself makes perfect use of the story and Japanese folklore to convey a strong story of courage and determination. He is currently one of my favorite directors. I plan on watching Studio Ghibli's other works in the near future. For now, I recommend that you all stop what you're doing and go watch this masterpiece. This is what true cinema looks like

An exercise in imagination.  So this is about a 10-year-old girl named Chihiro (Rumi Hiiragi).  Her family is in the process of moving to the suburbs, and they explore the nearby area when they make a wrong turn getting to their new house.  It turns out to be quite the fateful event because Chihiro soon finds herself in a spell-filled world of spirits.  When her parents transform into pigs, it's all up to her to find a remedy and form an escape plan.  Now anime is admittedly a big blind spot for me.  For years I dug my feet in and refused to watch it because there's such an extensive number of options that I didn't know where to start.  It's the same reason I've never really explored Bollywood.  However, I am making small steps to fix that, and I am currently enjoying the ride with my first series, Evangelion.  I decided to watch arguably the most acclaimed anime movie of all time, and Spirited Away is nothing short of wonderful.  Now, even though I am pretty green with anime, this is one of maybe two anime features I've watched in the past.  It was back when I started seriously getting into movies, so I would guesstimate that to be about fifteen years ago.  After all, I was looking at lists like the IMDb top 250 at the time, and this is universally rated highly, so why wouldn't I watch it?  I'm pretty sure I watched the dubbed version at the time, which is not something I did this time around.  Rewatching this was a great experience because I remembered next to nothing about it other than that image of a train ride with the masked character, so it was like I was watching it with fresh eyes.  Right away, this story entices you with mystery.  Sure, these are kind of terrible parents, but their shortcomings are the means to take you to this incredibly well-thought-out world.  They do a fantastic job of pulling you in because they don't take any time at all to lay out the rules.  This is a land where literally anything can happen, and you have to go along for the ride.  Oh, the parents are pigs now?  You don't have time to think about it because now there are ghosts, talking frogs, and a man with six extendable arms.  You can call this the Japanese Alice in Wonderland, and that would be fairly accurate.  I would argue that this is far more substantial because there is so much more character growth that comes with interesting character choices that are made throughout.  The world-building in this is nothing short of incredible, and this is a place that feels lived in at every turn.  This is a movie that fires on all cylinders.  The animation is standout, the score is terrific, and the pacing is taut.  Even if you were like the old me and resisted anime, you should make an exception for this one.

A deeper interpretation of "Spirited Away" reveals its author's true intent: investigate the loss of identity and analyze the authenticity dilemma.
Miyazaki criticizes contemporary Japanese society, dominated by consumerism and indolence, greedy like the protagonist's parents.
In the first sequence we see Chihiro, a listless and disenchanted girl who wears an oversized T-shirt, shorts and sneakers. Western clothes in clear contrast to the traditional uniform she wears once she "becomes" Sen.
The change coincides with the meeting with Yubāba who, thanks to a magic spell capable of stealing identities and memories, takes part of her name away (千 Sen is the first character of 千尋 Chihiro).
The dualism in "Spirited Away" (tradition and modernity, East and West) represents a strong conflict that converges in a profound crisis of identity. Haku is unable to remember his real name; No-Face is looking for a place to stay and be accepted; the River Spirit needs to be purified in order to return to its original form.
The confused cultural hybridism disorients and frightens the young protagonist who, however, finds the determination and the courage to assert herself and accomplish her coming-of-age. Chihiro/Sen will go back to wearing her old clothes, reaffirming her Westernized identity, but only after having rediscovered her roots, Japanese tradition, and the intrinsic authenticity of her physical and spiritual journey.
In "Spirited Away" we find all the themes dear to Miyazaki: environmentalism, socialism, the ambiguity of good and evil. But, also, the critique of capitalism and globalization, which deprives the meaning of imported ideas and discredits the local ones.
But "Spirited Away" is also, and above all, a visually splendid, delicate, rich and sincere film; perfectly edited and marvelously portrayed by its animated characters. It is a masterpiece of craftsmanship that finally consecrates Miyazaki's genius internationally, not only for animation but for cinema in general, spreading his aesthetic throughout the world.

There's a reason Spirited Away won the Oscar for Best Animated Feature — it's what animated movies are all about. Master animator, Hayao Miyazaki, creates a surreal world of talking frogs, bulbous witches, depressed spirits, and slithery wolf-dragons. The landscapes and food in Studio Ghibli movies always appear sublime. Chihiro (Daveigh Chase), a ten-year-old who is lashing out because she doesn't want to move, is thrust into the dreamscape after only a few minutes in an abandoned amusement park — her parents (Michael Chiklis & Lauren Holly) gorge themselves on unattended food, quickly morphing into ravenous pigs. Spirited Away nails the subtlety of intertwining overarching issues — environmentalism, consumerism, modernity vs. tradition — into the whimsical coming-of-age story. Kamaji (David Ogden Stiers), "the spider-man," is the epitome of a Ghibli character — he's supernatural with an arch in his relationship with our protag and possesses a big heart. There are countless scenes where Miyazaki flexes his animation muscles, but my favorite comes with Haku (Jason Marsden) when he's in dragon form. It'd been a decade since I last watched this movie and it reminded me of what had made it so special. 20 years later, Spirited Away is still a must-watch and (so far) my favorite Studio Ghibli story.

I love Studio Ghibli, and Spirited Away is one of my favourite films from the studio. This is coming from someone who was delighted by Howl's Moving Castle, blown away by Princess Mononoke, emotionally devastated by Grave of the Fireflies and touched by the simplicity of The Cat Returns all but to name a few. Spirited Away is a mystical, charming and truly enchanting animated fantasy, even with the long length and some slow moments. The animation is absolutely stunning, both the hand drawn visuals and the CGI graphics give an ethereal charm to the film. The characters move more than convincingly and the colours are beautiful. The music is also outstanding, I loved the simplicity of the piano and the drama of the more dramatic parts. The story is a pleasure, I know people have complained of some loose ends, but it is an original, touching and charming one I feel. I also loved the characters. Chihiro, voiced with real enthusiasm by Daveigh Chase, is sulky to begin with, but she is also brave and resourceful, traits I like in young heroines. Lin is kind and sympathetic, and Susan Egan who was also in Porco Rosso was unusually sensitive as the character. Jason Marsden is charming as Haku, and Suzanne Pleshette is perfect as the grotesque Yubaba and as her sister Zeniba. Overall, I loved Spirited Away, it is really charming. 10/10 Bethany Cox

First let me say that I love how beautiful this film is and how easy on the eyes it is… sure, you can say that for most animated films, but Spirited Away truly stands out and is in a category of it's own. This is simply the best cartoon ever made and I watched it a dozen times before writing this review.  Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful to look at, a complex story and so different (I believe) from anything made outside Japan.  Absolutely spellbinding viewing for young children and adults alike.  
It's an imaginative tale of courage and love, above all - love of family, friends and more.  These universal themes are mixed with magic, monsters, myth and legend.  Don't turn away at this point - it could be like a lot of other cartoons but it isn't.  You grow to love and hate the extraordinary characters and the scenery is the most gorgeous I have ever seen in an animated feature.  You could put any still from the film on your wall and just sit and admire it.
The score is splendid too and the song over the closing credits (in Japanese) will make you weep; maybe that's because by the time you get to it, you will know you're in the presence of greatness.

If Gabriel Garcia Marquez took mushrooms and tried to write a kid's movie, you'd get Spirited Away. It's the Alice in Wonderland of the 21st century: it watches like a waking dream. Its horrors are like nightmares you want to wake up from but can't. Its euphoria dances in technicolor. It is just as original and perplexing as the dream world. And like dreams, there are lessons present for those who would look, though they may take some work to translate to a usable form. The themes of solitude, change, despair, absurdity, and redemption are woven throughout its impressive animated antics. More than any other movie, I find myself wanting to show Spirited Away to friends and family who've never seen it.

I watched Spirited Away as a kid, when my then-weeb sister forced me to. We had to share our computer time and she forced me to sit there and watch this. I didn't like this film at all, and was constantly throwing a tantrum at every scene. First of all I had never liked anime, probably my sister had heard about this from school. And secondly I could have been playing browser games instead of watching this. But now when I look back at it, this is one of the best anime films I have watched. However, since I saw this film over twelve years ago, my knowledge is not very fresh and I might make some mistakes while writing this review.
As I have grown into becoming an artist now, the idea of this film has started to make sense. The film begins in an absolutely surreal manner. The idea behind the girl's parents turning into pigs after eating like them is quite scary, which is exactly what the film wants us to feel. I remember I was thinking why she doesn't sit and eat with them. I have always been such a foodie, I might have as well ended up like them if I were there. And then this girl had to run away and live among the monsters. Each one of them was traumatising, except the woman whom Spider-Eggman convinces by giving her a roasted lizard.
Now I won't go too much in detail for the characters or the story, since I don't think I remember anything correctly. As I write this review I am getting occasional glimpse of some scenes, particularly the slime monster one. So all I'm gonna talk about are the other aspects of this film. First of all, this film is a dream for any postmodernist art lover. The idea of random things happening, the characters who can only exist in a fever dream interacting with the girl and the old woman - everything about this is like something Salvador Dali would be proud of.
The only problem I had in this film is from the plot holes. I could be wrong since I watched it so long back, that too while throwing a tantrum and not wanting to watch this film (I have completely forgotten the part where the black Shy Guy meets the girl; I believe it happens in this film?). The part where the girl tries cleaning the muck from the bath and the slime monster gets upset and start chasing her; how do they suddenly become friends? Just because the monster got tired from chasing her? That scene has never made any sense to me. Also who was that boy who came in the beginning? How come he never got to do the work the girl was doing, irrespective of whether he himself was a monster or a human? Either way it makes the film look like a nightmare, which I'm pretty sure it wasn't trying to.
Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi (this is the actual name of this film) is the first and by far the only Hayao Miyazaki film I have seen. Even though I don't know much about his signature style, this film gave me a vague idea of how he is different from the conventional anime artists. In case all his films are like this, I'd really hope to see them all. And I'd personally want to apologise for the bad time I gave my sister while watching it.

Hayao Miyazaki's family fantasy anime film Spirited Away (2001) is a coming of age masterpiece of hand drawn animation. Every scene like in Spirited Away is like a flowing river of paintings, lovingly hand drawn by Japan's Studio Ghibli. Miyazaki's direction is incomparable really as he juxtaposes frightening bath house chases with tranquil train rides over water for his spirit world adventure. 

Miyazaki must have overlooked this entire picture's production from start to end as everything is sublime from Ghibli's radiant lighting, vibrant color palette, fluid motion, and tender emotion in every frame of Spirited Away. Few films will ever measure up to the legacy Spirited Away has left as every anime film after it is compared to it. Spirited Away is animated perfection for all ages to marvel at forevermore.

Hayao Miyazaki's writing is phenomenal fun with affectionate empathy for the feelings of a little girl moving to a new town, only to lose her parents to a curse that transforms them into pigs. Miyazaki's story bears timeless themes about growing up and moving on from our past, so that we might look bravely towards the future with new eyes and a strong heart for change. 

Miyazaki's anime narrative is fascinating as he parallels a girl getting whisked off to the spirit world, forced into an evil witch's contract as a bath house maid for spirits with the scary feelings that come with moving. Her various encounters with spirits, witches, dragons, frogs, and pigs represent the many anxiety inducing scenarios we must face in life with a thorough uncertainty. I appreciate how Miyazaki's words shape Spirited Away's story into a triumph of courageously rising to challenges like meeting strangers, facing danger, acquiring work, befriending people, falling in love, finding yourself, and growing up. Spirited Away is a lovingly crafted anime for anyone to relate to Chihiro's emotional odyssey.

Takeshi Seyama's editing is strikingly cut with hard cuts from action sequences to quiet passages of reflection that I really like. Seyama's steadfast editing has long held Miyazaki's pictures to nicely paced adventures and finely cut feature lengths. Spirited Away is a long 125 minutes that you'll never notice the run-time, because Seyama keeps it moving from strange new dilemma to new sequences quickly. Atsushi Okui's cinematography is perhaps his finest camera decisions with breathtaking wide shots of the water viewed from the spirit train. His mysterious shots for the nighttime at the bath house are riveting.

Norobu Yoshida's production design is mesmerizing from the spirit tunnel that appears to be an old abandoned train station, the intricate bath house for spirits, the decaying carnival for souls, the peaceful spirit train to the serene woods, and the little car Chihiro's parents drive all have neat designs. Yoji Takeshige's art direction is beautiful with flowing water leading into large baths or a dragon flying through the air above water. Spirited Away is like feeling the air brush past your face with a cool breeze. Thomas Baker's effects are crazy for No Face's engorged belly and magical transformations from man into dragon with this glittering shimmer.

Joe Hisaishi's transcendent piano driven score for Spirited Away is simply divine. You are captivated by every note and melody. Hisaishi's music captures the freedom and innocence of youthful wonder, first love, and a sense of adventure. He also finds a frightening eeriness for the scary sequences with a thundering roar of fear cascading over you with unsettling grace. I guarantee everyone seeing Spirited Away will immediately fall hopelessly in love with Joe Jisaishi's lovely score.

I should mention that I adore the English Dub of Spirited Away. Daveigh Chase is wondrous as the brave girl Chihiro with her sympathetic voice and endless expressiveness. Jason Marsden is likable as the enigmatic Haku. His serious guidance is as involving as his quick expressions of adoration for Chihiro. He's just perfect as Haku. Suzanne Pleshette is excellent as the fearsome witch Yubaba as well as the kindly witch sister Zeniba. Suan Egan is amazing as Chihiro's fiercely independent and helpful friend Lin at Yubaba's bath house. Her lively personality and iconic voice always delights me to hear again.

Lauren Holly is nice as Chihiro's passive sounding mother, while Michael Chiklis is great as Chihiro's excitable father. David Ogden Stiers is really outstanding as the stern boiler room warlock Kamaji with a sweet softer side as he warms up to Chihiro as Sen. John Ratzenberger even cameos as the flippant foreman.

In the end, Spirited Away is a movie worth watching to cheer you up and let you appreciate life with a renewed vigor.

Una película animada que atraviesa la experiencia humana.

El lugar al que Chihiro se ve arrojada es muy similar a la experiencia humana, al vernos arrojados a esta vida y planeta. Para nosotros como observadores externos la estética y comportamiento pueden parecer alienantes, sin embargo en ellos he encontrado palpables similitudes con el actuar de las personas. 

Entre lo delirante de los seres que habitan la temporal morada de Chihiro, emergen dinámicas sociales, valores, ficciones, costumbres, antagonismos, como una sociedad encapsulada. Así pues de nuestras alucinaciones, nacen la justicia, las naciones, el sentido de la verdad, el bien, la identidad... como primates delirantes arrojados a un jardín esférico mayormente verde y azul.

Una tristeza inicial que con el pasar de los años desemboca en los mejores casos en sabiduría, conforme nos aclimatamos al mundo que nos rodea, tal como sucede con Chihiro. La traducción de personajes inanimados de la vida de Chihiro en seres vivientes evoca en mí el mundo interior de las intenciones, el niño que siempre busca un sentido superior a lo que sucede al rededor. ¿Qué es esto si no la espiritualidad?

Esto no significa que la película trate de predicar al espectador, todo lo que he mencionado anteriormente expresa mi experiencia personal, la cual esta altamente sujeta a mis experiencias previas. La película se limita a contar la historia, y jamás explica o busca dar trascendencia a lo sucedido, pues es el espectador quien la encuentra o ignora. Aún así cada escena se siente llena de propósito y cuidadoso pensamiento, cada línea de diálogo es significativo.

Con su mundo fantasioso, surrealista, para algunos bizarro, El Viaje de Chihiro en mí ha proyectado una imagen sumamente realista de mi experiencia como ser humano, pues ha estimulado nociones tempranas, profundas y persistentes de mi consciente y subconsciente

Una obra que ha tocado las fibras más entrañables de mi ser.

Spirited Away is one of the most perfect movies I have ever seen. The least I can say about it is that there was not a single moment during it that my attention wasn't completely focused. The plot was fantastic and full-bodied. Each character was given so much personality, even the little soot spiders weren't treated as two-dimensional.

In a way the whole film felt like a dream, in that it is seamless. It flows, effortlessly, from scene to scene, from emotion to emotion - straight from terror and tragedy to comedy - without the subtle bump that wakes you up, that lets you know that the makers of the movie and the creator of the script had wanted you to be crying but now you really should be laughing. It was so LIFELIKE. Sometimes in real life the most grim moments contain honest elements of comedy that do not seem out-of-place. But trying to put that sort of convoluted emotion into a film creates a very thin line that too many have fallen off of.

There was no part of the film that felt fake, or rushed, or shaky; the intensity of the story line and the determination of the lead character was obvious throughout. More than causing interest, this movie made me FEEL. I was sucked into the drama. I can rarely say that a movie made me laugh and cry without feeling like an idiot, but the caliber of this picture is so high that I don't even feel embarrassed. I laughed. I cried. And you will too.

Along with Totoro, likely the greatest film to come out of the venerable Studio Ghibli. The worldbuidling is sensational, you can slip into it like a warm bath. The characters are fascinating and creative, the plot is engaging (simultaneously dangerous, whimsical, and enticing), and the animation is flat-out second to none. Contrast Spirited Away with the studio's follow-up film, The Cat Returns, and you might join me in wondering how the latter has anywhere near the same degree of critical acclaim, unless it's just spill-over that has lingered after the sublime move-going experience that is Spirited Away. Takahata's a genius, but Miyazaki is really the only director that can make deep Japanese folklore so enticing for an international audience (looking at you, Pom Poko). (5/5)

A girl went to a place that is different from reality because people could use magic and there were a lot of unique living things. Her parents changed pigs by eating food from a different world. As she worked in a hot spring to save her parents, she met a boy and the boy helped her adapted this place. She grew up through extraordinary adventures. 
When I watched it, I loved this film and it was wonderful. First, I liked the expression to depict building, water, landscape, and people. I have watched other films by Hiyao Miyazaki a lot. Moreover, I was satisfied with the fantasy point because I cannot do it. So, by watching this film, I wanted to experience and see the adventure and fantasy-like flying the sky.

Although people do not watch a film, they already know the music. I also listened to music before watched the film. When I listened to the music in the film, I was surprised. After the movie watched it, I can imagine the scene of the film and make me feel happy.
In the film, the direction did not just make this animation for children. He wanted to give special messages. He criticized the old culture of Japan in a hot spring. I recommend it to people.

Summary
Spirited Away is an anime movie about a girl called Chirico (Daveigh Elizabeth Chase) who has moved to a different home with her family, they start venturing some old ruins of the town but everything changes when her mum and dad turn into pigs and cruel looking spirits start coming out. Suddenly a boy called Haku  (Jason Christopher Marsden) takes Chirico to safety. The poor girl realizes that she is in a spirited world and she starts working in the hotel there. Chirico will do anything to get out but along the way she makes some friends.

After watching this movie I was completely blown away at how breathtaking and immersive Miyazaki's work is. The stunning visuals and animation were gorgeous and drew me into the seemingly impossible world he created. The beautiful soundtrack complements the movie so well and the simple piano piece was tear jerking even in the first few minutes it was in. The unique characters had a charm unlike any other, and it was fascinating to follow Chihiro around through this strange dreamlike world, and watch her transform into a strong young woman. Watch this movie. Spirited away is one of the most popular anime films in this part of the world. It won an Oscar for best animated movie, beating Disney and Dreamworks in 2002. Its ending is quite different from any other anime films around and I think that's what gives the film a remarkable status compared to other Studio Ghibli works, It's got a more western ending than the classic, open to interpretation anime ending. To me, it's a great film with some of the most memorable characters in the studio's history, but it's not even close to other Ghibli films. Hayao Miyazaki is an expert creating wonderful, compelling characters, to the point where we forget that the story those characters received might make very little sense. Spirited Away is that movie that you watched when you were young and it changed your life, but everytime you rewatch it you wonder what was so great about it in the first place.

Spirited Away is an adventure. As Miyazaki's possibly most well known film, it serves as a jumping off point for most fans and does so in the most exciting way. The whole movie has a very colorful art style which perfectly mimics all of the colorful characters that our protagonist interacts with. She is able to build meaningful relationships with people that just want to help her or don't even talk. There are many smaller plots scattered throughout to show our leading lady's struggle and since each of these subplots have their own ups and downs you stay engaged at all times. Overall Spirited Away does what most Miyazaki films do which is transport the audience into a world that seems incredibly fantastic in comparison to our own. You feel real emotion and a lot of the plot holds a deeper meaning (so much so that I don't understand most).

Director Hayao Miyazaki is a master in the field; he's brought to life some of the most memorable animated characters outside of Disney themselves. Studio Ghibli is a Japenese animation studio (on the same level as Disney, and they've only been around since '85).

Spirited Away is a story about a Chihiro, a 10-year-old girl who, while moving to a new city, has an adventure of a lifetime. She enters the spirit world of Japanese folklore, a world of gods, and spirits, where everything you think you know is wrong.

It ranks on several of the best films of the 21st century lists in the top five (and that placement is more than deserved). If you've never watched an anime, this would be my suggestion on where to start. If you enjoy it, you can move onto Princess Mononoke, My Neighbor Totoro, Akira, Howl's Moving Castle, Grave of the Fireflies (careful, this one can make even the toughest person shed a tear!), or a countless list of others that offer up something that traditional American animation doesn't.

The best thing about foreign animation is that you don't have to rely on reading subtitles; most have been dubbed in English (oftentimes being a seamless transition).

I really, really didn't like Spirited Away as an adult or a kid. It feels messy, and as a kid, just kinda weirded me out. There's no real growth or progression, but it feels like a 6 year old playing with a dollhouse with a "and then this happened" plot. The use of magic felt inconsistent, the parents were punished but never had to learn anything (because they were turned to pigs arbitrarily to advance the plot), and the climax of the movie of the girl looking through the pigs to see if her parents were in the group, was just a gut feeling, not choice that she made out of the knowledge that she obtained from the rest of the film, as would have happened in a decent movie.

If Spirited Away was released now with computer graphics, it would be mocked and dismissed as trash, because the only two decent characters in the film were the hungry garbage ghost, and the dragon kid. The whole thing needed a rewrite, and should have had much more of a "Willy Wonka" vibe in my opinion, with the child learning from the mistakes of the adults in her life or something.
Spirited Away benefits from the incredible talent at Studio Ghibli in this brilliantly animated and emotional journey that captures the mind and heart while never letting go.

Spirited Away is bizarre. So unlike anything I'd seen when I first watched it, and I'm not particularly into Japanese anime. Little did I know its director, Hayao Miyazaki, would become such a world-changing part of my love for movies. Having watched it (so many times!), I can now say that Spirited Away is one of the most beautiful movies I have ever seen.

In this curious and lovely tale, Chihiro (Rumi Hiiragi; Ponyo, From Up on Poppy Hill), grumpy about moving to a new home and new school, apprehensively follows her parents into what appears to be an abandoned theme park. But once the sun sets, a hidden world comes to life and Chihiro realizes, to her horror, that her parents have fallen under a dreadful enchantment.

In order to earn her parents' freedom and escape the enchanted world she had stumbled into, she must befriend a charming crew of different creatures and serve in a bathhouse under the mysterious witch Yubaba (Mari Natsuki).

Spirited Away is gorgeous, yet grotesque. You never know whether a scene will portray a glorious sunset over a bridge, or a gigantic river god vomiting the sludge of a thousand years' pollution. Somehow, the heart and skill of the Studio Ghibli team manage to balance the quaint and adorable with the dark, disturbing, and weighty. There is always something happening in each frame; I guarantee you can watch, re-watch, and keep re-watching because (like all Miyazaki movies) it is crammed full of surprises and delights.

Miyazaki is one of the most important cinematic warriors for children and feminism today. Most of his animated tales feature brave young women, usually children, and they are masterfully complex. Miyazaki's women are neither damsels nor dominatrixes, and his children are portrayed just as children are in real life: learning, growing, tiny versions of real people. Nowhere is this more apparent than in Chihiro's story.

I freaking love this unique coming-of-age tale about the power of love, trust, and kindness to overcome darkness, greed, and loneliness. It's full of dragons, ghosts, monsters, and the most adorable dust bunnies I've ever seen in my life.

I was absolutely spirited away.
 
----------

Editor's note: While there is a solid English-language dubbed version of Spirited Away, this reviewer recommends the Japanese-language version with English subtitles to best capture the spirit of the strange and interesting characters. Certain voices and tones are quite different in the English version, which could make a big difference to a first-time viewer's experience!

Spirited away is a wonderful movie, that is able to teach you and deliver many messages no matter how many times you watch it. It is about a girl named Chihiro, who is moving into a new house but her parents turn down the wrong road. She ends up losing her parents and traveling the spirit world alone with a boy named Haiku and a girl named Elizabeth to help her and look for her parents who have turned to pigs. The main point of spirit away is how good conquerors evil. Spirited Away is a extraordinary, movie because it is able to express different emotions throughout the movie, Although different scenes can be a little intimidating, the graphics are extraordinary and are able to capture a very detailed panoramic, with a beautiful artful balance between terror and joy, and each character if just filled with so much personality and not treated as a 2 dimensional object. However it can be breathtaking, it can also be so intense at times that your heart seems to stop and then rest go into a resting pace again.
Some scenes in Spirited Away can be very intimidating at times, such as being a young girl who has to face a crowd of jangling, wildy variegated horde of frogmen, river-dragons, nameless ooze-beasts, radish giants, and above all, the witch Yubaba, A huge-headed, bejeweled monstrosity who steals names and memories. Chihiro (who is the young girl) has to face these horrifying monstrosities, which make her believe at first that she is dreaming, and has to eat spirit food so she does not have to disintegrate with the spirits yet. She is at a young age she, and really should not be the one to suffer from her parents doing, Luckily she is able to have friends that are willing to help her along the way. This captures such an amazing tale of how one little girl can go be strong and courageous just because she wants to save her parents. (Not only does she want them but she needs them.)
The graphics in Spirited Away are extraordinary, It really shows how Miyazaki (The producer) is able to portray wit and playfulness and charm mixed into the proceedings. The cool part about it, it is all hand drawn and then it is all digitised. "Yet it has a dazzling quality, which has a fleetness and lightness in the way that switches from the close-up on a deft little sight gag or a sweet character observation, sweeping out for a breathtaking panorama of an extraterrestrial landscape imagined with  passionate detail and specificity. The whole film in a way felt as if it all was a dream and that is seamless. It flows without any effort  from scene to scene, from emotion to emotion straight from tragic to comedy.  This shows that it took a long time to actually create this masterpiece, before they digitize everything they have to hand drawn the characters and their amazingly detailed surroundings, which probably took them awhile to put so much detail into one paper and then making a movie out of it with perfect meaning and fantastic graphics, it is just mind boggling. This is why Spirited away is one of the most mass appealed and was one of the best animated movies that was able to win the top prize at the Berlin festival.
This Breathtaking movie puts so much personality into characters that even little things that you can treat as objects have a personality of its own. Spirited away is adjusted for all audiences especially american audiences. Spirited away's breath and heart, gave it the appeal that should touch all american viewers. This film is able to truly transport their viewers outside themselves-- or deep inside. But even the small soot balls in the film have a personality and are their own characters. Even though some things like soot balls you wouldn't think you could give them personality but Miyazaki (The producer) is able to think outside the box and give objects and things there own personality and make the movie a lot more Child-like and puts a little bit more character into each of his characters he comes up with which really brings this horrific movie together, without him this movie probably would not have been such a great success.
    This film is so captivating, yes some parts of the film can be intimidating but this brave young girl is willing to risk everything to save her parents. The graphics are superb, each picture was hand drawn with a lot of detail and then digitized which is why it was considered the top winner of the Berlin festival. Each character was not treated as 2 dimensional, the characters all have their own little personality including the small soot balls that would carry the lumps of coal into the fire with their small little arms and legs. Spirited Away is such a wonderful and moving movie  in so many ways, each scene flows so seamlessly, without abrupt stops. There are times in the movie where you can cry and not feel like an idiot, because it is such a work of art that is able to pool a lot of meaning into this movie.

I do wish that there was a bit more logic or explanation of how this spirit world works, because that was the part that I could not follow.   Its interesting how this film walks just on the edge of being too scary and strange for kids, but also feels like it is totally targeted at kids.  As an adult there were some elements that felt a little too childish in their execution, but I connected with the characters just fine.  This also might be the best dubbed voicework Ive ever heard on a Miyazaki movie (Im not a big fan of subtitles.)  The line delivery is much more natural, instead of feeling oddly rushed and stilted.  My only real complaint about Spirited Away is how odd the world was, to the point that it felt like there were no rules to how it all worked.  When a person can be randomly cut in half and then be fine two scenes later, I start to wonder if this world makes any sense at all.  Again, I respect the elaborate and unique world created in Spirited Away, I just prefer my fantasy worlds to still have some type of logic in them.  All that said, its still my favorite Miyazaki film because I was genuinely invested in the story and definitely never bored.

This movie is so amazing and perfectly crafted that I am at an utter loss of words just trying to properly describe how great it really is! I don't care if you're not into anime, EVERYONE should check this masterpiece of a movie out no matter what!

Wow, this movie hasn't even really started and I can tell it's already going to be beautiful. I love the artwork in this movie. Miyazaki's use of spirits is always inspiring and wonderful. All these different creatures are so interesting to watch how they interact with each other. 

Those black fluff balls are so cute. Seeing the inner workings of the bath house is mind boggling. There's so much that seems to be going on. This movie is about a lot of things. But mainly it's about a girl who is becoming independent and mature.  
 
There's some really well thought out original ideas in this movie that are just really inspiring. I loved the whole metaphor of the big slime creature who came and got washed up. It turns out he was overly materialistic and greedy stocking up on all these things he didn't need and in the end after he got washed up, he left a clean spirited man, leaving all his gold and possessions behind. 

That whole concept of the spirit train really hit me when I saw all these working class spirits getting off I guess to go home. And then I got to thinking, maybe in the afterlife, some people continue working and never go to paradise. It was a pretty haunting thought. Just like always, love trumps all can fix any situation. The mouse and the bird characters were so cute. And seeing the difference of how the two witch sisters live is a very important thing to note, because in the end it dictates there personalities. Hearing that the guy's voice of Haku is the same one who does voices in Skyrim, was great. I can't help but feel kind of worried for Chihiro, given that her life doesn't seem like it's the greatest since. Her parents don't seem to care too much. But knowing that she's still protected by the hair tie they gave her, is a nice touch and a great way to end the movie. 

Overall, amazing film. One of the most beautifully animated films ever to come out. Once again, Miyazaki and his team took me on another wonderful cinematic adventure filled with joy, humor, charm, and important lessons in life. This is a great movie about a girl beginning to blossom and get out of her shell and become a teen.

L'animation est cependant exceptionnelle et le score de Joe Hisaishi, bien que moins légendaire que ses précédents, est au diapason. Chihiro est tout de même le premier film de Miyazaki qui ne donne pas l'impression d'une véritable création et c'est vraiment le problème.

After reading such great reviews about this film by critics for so long, I was thrilled to finally watch it.  It shows up on many top critics' lists as one of the greatest films of its genre.  I had recently seen "My Neighour Totoro" and enjoyed it immensely.

I was let down.  This is so far overrated by the groupthink of critics that are afraid to step out of the box to go against the grain of their elitist community.  It is still a great movie.  However, it is nowhere near my expectation of a 10/10.

The film is well written, well produced and has some stunning visuals.  The animation is a little too "choppy" for my comfort.  The depth of the story and characters are very strong, definitely making this a great animated film.  The story is complex and pure fantasy.  This is not Disney fare.  However, the story became too complex for my taste.  The beauty of My Neighbour Totoro was the simplistic aesthetic of the story.  This plot has 2-3x more characters and plot twists that are largely left unexplained.   

The film is bizarre.  Much more so than My Neighbour Totoro, which was likely the most bizarre children's film I had ever seen.  This would never have been produced in America as it is so far off the historical, Hollywood box office formula for children's movies.   

Spirited Away should be a benchmark for other animators to follow.  I believe it will hold its place in the history of animation for decades to come and could very well be an epic, if it is not one already.

Spirited Away shows many aspects of Japanese culture including the Shinto religion. This is represented by the many spirits that take on the identity of real world objects, landmarks, rivers and even food. The movie describes how we are connected to these things. What we do and how we live our lives affect us more than we think. As you watch Spirited Away try to look for Shinto references. They will make the movie more interesting as you watch and recognize these things.

Beguiling and breathtakingly crafted, one of the best animation creators living today,  Japanese filmmaker Hayao Miyazaki has done it again by creating another master piece after his well-known film Princess Mononoke with his new animation Spirited Away. This animation Spirited Away conveys its audience to another realm and universe to edify us, on how to find our true selves. 
As breath-taking as it is, this animation is often compared to an animation we all know, "Alice in Wonderland". This animation revolves around a sullen, whinny ten year old girl named Chihiro who wanders to a different realm of spirits, gods and mysterious creatures. Chihiro enters the realm when she flees after seeing her parents turn into pigs after they had devoured some spirit food they had randomly found in an abandoned town. As she runs away from all the bizarre events happening, she meets her first friend, Haku (a river god) who later helps her find a job at the Bath house. It is important to keep in mind that the bath house is the main setting for this animation, therefore it holds a lot of significances of how Chihiro finds her true self.
 Working in the bath house and having to lose her name "Chihiro" to Yubaba (the spirit owner of the bath house), Chihiro has to take on a new moniker of "Sen" and learn how to not be a jackanapes girl she used to be when her parents was there to spoil her. Being "Sen" Chihiro does not forget her real name, therefore she is not like Haku who does not remember his name, as a result of forgetting his name, he is under the control of Yubaba making himself who he really is not.  
One of the messages that Hayao Miyazaki wanted us to get out of the animation itself is never forget your identity, who you are or you will become someone who you aren't like Haku. Hayao Miyazaki also uses the Bath house as a symbol of the Japanese identity so that the Japanese people do not forget their history and who they are. Another Message that we get from this animation is greed. In this animation we see many forms of greed but Chihiro never showed any greed and at the end, she was better off than those who were greedy in the animation. 
I want to say that this is by far this is one of the best animations created. Why? The reason is how this film was made. Instead of using and relying on computers and technology to help draw the frames of the animation, Hayao Miyazaki draws each and every one of the thousand frames there is by hand. It is also amazing how the Japanese voice actors Miyu Irino (Haku), Rumi Hiiragi (Chihiro), Mari Natsuki (Yubaba and Zeniba) and Bunta Sugawara (Kamaji) can put the liveness into this animation. To record animations, it takes a lot of skills. Why? Because the cast has to be able to match the characters mouthing with their vocals to make it seem as if the characters are actually talking. In general, the Japanese cast does an amazing job by portraying their emotions and vocals into these characters therefore, this animation to me was one of the many animations that I found amusing and enchanting.  
In Most of his animations, Hayao Miyazaki focuses on the theme spirituality. As this animation Spirited Away progresses, we as the audience may get enchanted into this realm along with Chihiro and be able to find our true selves. Through Spirited Away Hayao Miyazaki provides his audience with a light that will help us guide our way to find our true selves through the dark. By finding our true selves, we can fully understand our true identity, and open the doors to self-acceptance.

This is my first exposure to Hayao Miyazaki's visual story telling.  The visual language has a lower tonal intensity than most recent Disney or Pixar productions, but it is effective in telling the story with a measured pace and meaningfulness.  

This story reminds me of Narnia, with the wardrobe as the portal in and out of another world.  However, the theology is quite different. This is solidly based on an animism tendency, perhaps with various shades of Shinto.  There is no transcending God.  Instead, there is the humanistic empathy and compassion as the emotional atmosphere, while the Duty and Love as the twin cores of the value.  

The most remarkable aspect is the value of "work" - here is the menial slavery of cleaning floors and bath tubs - as the savior of one's own spirit and others.  Our heroine's work did not have much value nor glory, yet she was transformed by the hard-work. 

There are some similarity of negative values such as the gluttony and greed, and a gentle goading to the overweening maternal instinct. 

This is a very good movie for children and adults!

Haku said that if you forget your real name, you couldn't go back to real world. When Chihiro went to Yubaba's office, she wrote her name on a paper, but she took a small mistake unconsciously. It mean she started to forget her name. Animated movies have a lack impact? That's not! This movie is really clear and significant. Finally, this movie is really interesting, deep and also include great animated views and expressions, so I like this movie and I think you'll like it!

A young girl is drawn into a transparent world populated by gods, spirits, monsters and fantasies, where she struggles to understand the ground rules amidst the bustle of a busy bath house. This setting - unmistakably Japanese - provides endless amounts of nourishment as a massive showpiece of imagination, attention to detail, fancy, delight and cultural lore. There's more going on in the backdrops of Spirited Away's throwaway scenes than many of its contemporaries can manage to plaster up-front and center. It's a bit less focused than Princess Mononoke, which preceded it in the Miyazaki timeline, but that's because it's such a decidedly different, strange creature altogether. Here we're taking the time to embrace and celebrate the inherent weirdness of Studio Ghibli's world, where I could happily sniff daisies and people-watch for the rest of my days. The primary storyline is steadfastly unpredictable, twisting and writhing like a wild beast caught on a leash, but is able to, with time, pluck most every last plot thread and leave us all with a deep sense of satisfaction. Ambitious, fiery, awe-inspiring and diverse, it's worth repeated viewings amidst audiences of all ages.
One of Anime's crowning achievements, and one of the greatest movies ever made.

Review In A Nutshell:

Spirited Away was the first film I have seen from legendary Hayao Miyazaki and expectations were high during my first viewing due to the hype that surrounds it. Many have rejoiced it as the shining example of the perfect Japanese animation. I sadly couldn't embrace the beauty that many seem to find in it. As of now, I have seen the film 4 times, and with each viewing I seem to gain a much better insight on its appeal, but it is still far from the general acclaim.

Spirited Away features an easy to follow story of a girl who ends up working for a spiritual bath house in order to save her parents, who have transformed into pigs. The events that happen throughout the film are certainly inventive, blowing away the imaginations that many animators or directors try to bring to life in animations. My primary issue with the film is its complexity in its themes. It is only during my previous viewing that I gained some sort of understanding on what Miyazaki was trying to explore. Spirited Away discusses the importance of hard work, that in order to get what we want, it must be earned. The film also explores the concept of identity and how when under the contract of your employer, one loses it. This was something that I felt, was true to life and also original in terms of cinematic themes. If only the film makes these easier to grasp, I wouldn't have too much of a problem with this film. The film is driven by these themes, rather than its superficial story, and if a film is going to take this route then it should make the road easier to drive on. The film also featured a couple of moments that dragged the pacing but fortunately it wasn't abundant enough to be labelled as a major issue.

Though most of what I have just said has been negative, the film does have its merits. The film is a visual delight with scene after scene of jaw dropping beautiful shots that rivals the best from Studio Ghibli. Another positive element was its musical score, with every couple of minutes had me in a state of merriment or grief; precisely hitting the emotional impact of its characters. The voice acting in this film was strong, I have seen Spirited Away in both Japanese and English and each one being remarkable.

I had hoped that maybe this time my opinion would drastically improve, but that was not the case. I highly doubt this time that my opinion would improve any higher, given that I have already seen this 4 times, but I definitely will not stop coming back to this film as its staggering visuals and blissfully beautiful score blew me away with each viewing.

Japanese animated fantasy, Spirited Away (Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi?, "Sen and Chihiro's Spiriting Away") is a 2001 film written and directed by Hayao Miyazaki and stars Rumi Hiiragi, Miyu Irino, Mari Natsuki, Takeshi Naito, Yasuko Sawaguchi, Tsunehiko Kamijo, Takehiko Ono and Bunta Sugawara. I will use one word to describe it - wonderful! 

It tells the story of Chihiro Ogino (Hiiragi), a ten-year-old girl who, while moving to a new neighbourhood, enters the spirit world. Stumbling on the food street in that world, her parents are transformed into pigs by the spell of the witch Yubaba (Natsuki), and Chihiro takes a job working in Yubaba's bathhouse to find a way to free herself and her parents and return to the human world.

Miyazaki's script was based on associate producer Seiji Okuda's ten-year-old daughter, who came to visit his house each summer. Production of the animated film began in year 2000 with a budget of US$19 million, but during production, Miyazaki realized the film would be over three hours long and decided to cut out several parts of the story. I wish I could see the rest of the story! English version of the film was supervised by the Pixar director John Lasseter, a fan of Miyazaki. Screenwriters Cindy Davis Hewitt and Donald H. Hewitt wrote the English-language dialogue, which they wrote to match the characters' original Japanese-language lip movements. I haven't seen that version, I enjoyed the original with subtitles.

Just to say that this is the most successful film in Japanese history, grossing about $270-350 million worldwide. The film even overtook Titanic (at the time the top grossing film worldwide) in the Japanese box office to become the highest-grossing film in Japanese history with a ¥30.4 billion total. Critics just love it, as the audience, and this animated movie is considered one of the best films of the 2000s decade and one of the greatest animated films of all time winning the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature at the 75th Academy Awards, the Golden Bear at the 2002 Berlin International Film Festival (tied with Bloody Sunday) and is among the top ten in the BFI list of the 50 films you should see by the age of 14. But , even if you are over 14, better now than never!

If you want an amazing out-of-this-world story, excellent animation where technology is kept at a level to enhance the story, not to "steal the show", perfect voice acting, meticulous editing, outstanding music... and many more things... please, spend over 2 hours watching this masterpiece!

Watching Spirited Away feels like opening a special gift. It is a film of such startling imagination, originality, intelligence, and emotion that I feel inexplicable joy. This movie starts with a young girl named Chihiro, who's really bummed out about moving to a new city where she won't be able to be with her old friends. Her mother and father are ready to move into their new home However, a wrong turn on the road leads them to a mysterious, abandoned theme park. Or so they think. It turns out that the family has stumbled upon a passage to the spirit world, with Chihiro's parents transformed into livestock after unknowingly consuming the food of the spirits without permission. Frightened and utterly alone, the only way for Chihiro to survive in this strange new world is to toil and work herself raw in a bathhouse run by a wicked sorceress.
The animation is so fluid and organic, the character design so colourful and twisted
It emphasizes on the beauty of traditionally drawn animations which in our times right now are being replaced by computer generated ones that lacks the colors, emotions, and depth of every line, texture, and detail that traditional drawing offers. The film is deeply dreamlike in places, particularly the scenes which take place in or around water and which are complimented. Miyazaki is not only good at dealing with light, but his darker tones are extraordinary too, from the thick sludge spewed forth by No-Face to the fire that spews from Yubaba's mouth. 
"Once you have met someone you never really forget them. It just takes a while for your memories to return". This is a famous quote from this movie. Every time when I think of this sentence, it remids me of the story filled with characters and moments that capture the essence of adventure.

01. Spirited Away 

And this is it: not only the best Ghibli ever, but the best movie ever. Intended for a 10 year old female audience, this proved to be the ideal target market for Miyazaki to play with, because while it remains 'safe for children', it does not shy away from the darkness, as our loveable Chihiro races through the strange (often terrifying) bathhouse of spirits, trying to break the pig curse placed on her parents and find her way back home. And don't forget the characters! A giant baby! Bouncing heads! Paper men armies! Adorable dust bunnies! Witches with faces the size of your body! That thing in the elevator! And literally hundreds more! But nothing can beat the disturbing No-Face, a complex lonely spirit who adapts the personalities of whoever he consumes, arguably the greatest character invention of all time. Which is why Spirited Away will always be remembered as Ghibli's most defining, essential piece, and not only because it's the most successful film in Japanese history or the studio's first Oscar winner, but because it's a modern day classic comparable to Alice in Wonderland, allowing the viewer to go as deep as they want to regardless of age. And that's simply perfect. 

To read the rest of my 'Worst to Best: Studio Ghibli' list, click here: http://juicenothing.blogspot.co.uk/2014/06/worst-to-best-studio-ghibli.html

I need to let go of my analytical mind. It nearly inhibited me from enjoying the fantastical spirit land that Spirited Away presents. So what if this is simply a tale of a girl named Chihiro who grows up in the spirit world through acts of selflessness? I accept archetypes. I am here to indulge in the undeniable beauty of the film's animation, and Miyazaki's imagination failed to disappoint. Don't misread what I say about the story as the movie being thoughtless, for how Miyazaki portrays characters is strongly connected with how these characters perform or develop. Humans turn into pigs for eating the spirits' food, while the gold-greedy spirits who work in the bathhouse resemble frogs. There are the spirits in the market square outside of the house that look near identical -- black, ghostly, faceless. The spirits on the train aren't much different, except they are dressed like travelers from an early film noir. One of these spirits, No-Face, wears a white mask to appear distinguished, and grows fond of the loving Chihiro (who loses her name in the bathhouse and becomes Sen). There are the two witches, Zeniba and Yubaba, that represent good and evil, respectively. Yubaba runs the bathhouse, with the assistance of her spirit slave Haku, whose forms include human and white, bird-legged Chinese dragon. The foreman of the house utilizes his infinite number of arms to direct water flow in each bath. He is also in charge of an army of ash mites that throw coal in a furnace to heat the water. I'm too sick to organize this information in any way. It was a joy to watch this.

The winner of the 2001 Academy Award for Best Animated Feature and arguably the most critically acclaimed film to be produced by Studio Ghibli, Spirited Away was only the second of Hayao Miyazaki's films I had seen after witnessing The Wind Rises.

When I walked away from Spirited Away, I walked outside the cinema into a world where everything seemed colourful and beautiful to me. I had my spirits lifted greatly by watching the film and experiencing the magical dark mystery of it, and I earned a new appreciation for the power of animated cinema and the skills of Hayao Miyazaki as a film director. 
Spirited Away is admirable for a lot of reasons, and it was the film that went to show me the endeavour of strength than anime cinema could have on a viewer. It did take me a little while to get into the swing of things because at first I found that the dark fantasy theme of the film was a little creepy. As I got sunk into the film more and more this feeling gradually faded away from me though I still knew it was there, but at the same time as having a certain sense of childish fear as a response to the darkness in the story, I also found it to be one of the film's greatest traits. Spirited Away respects its viewers enough not to degrade the darkness of its material down to a childish format. And while some viewers will find the dark nature of Spirited Away to be creepy, those who will appreciate the magical sense of mystery in it will truly enjoy the film.
I wasn't expecting Spirited Away to have the kind of impact on me that it did, but I was more than very pleased with the film. Its interpretation of the spirit world is excellent because it leaves audiences on edge about how to truly feel about it. While as a whole it depicts the spirit world as a dark place where black magic dominates with strength and leaves the people around to suffer under the tyrannical rule of the monetary focused with Yubaba. There is always a certain tension in Spirited Away due to its unpredictable and dark nature, so when the plot dynamics face a more optimistic light it is a feeling that viewers should truly treasure while they can. The mood is constantly intense in Spirited Away, and when it turns more positive for protagonist Chihiro, audiences are likely to feel the same thing. For an animated film, Spirited Away easily manages to have viewers empathising with its main character by having them feel the exact same thing as her, albeit from a third person perspective, so the feeling the viewer gets from watching Spirited Away is magnificent.
Spirited Away is unforgettable because of the complicated way that it depicts the spirit world. There is no way to tell what is going to come around the corner in Spirited Away because it could be literally anything. In a world where humans are turned into animals and forced to work under the rule of Yubaba, audiences are likely to end up raising a lot of questions which cannot physically be answered due to the mystery of the spirit world. The way it depicts the universe for better or for worse is just incredible. No live action film has ever depicted the spirit universe as well as Spirited Away did, and the fact that Hayao Miyazki took on the challenge with Studio Ghibli is excellent because they tackle the visual aspects of Spirited Away and its subject matter head on with honesty and ambition, and without fail they succeed in creating surreal and mysterious entertainment which is also thought provoking. It raises a lot of questions and brings out a lot of mythological elements such as dragons, ghosts and magic, and it touches upon them in the manner they are written to be without turning them into commercialised chilidish characters, so Spirited Away is a film I would recommend to children who are ready to take a step closer to the darker strengths of storytelling.
Despite a budget of a mere $19 million, Spirited Away features the some of the greatest quality anime that I have ever seen. The movements of the characters is very organic, and the entire universe of the film is very colourful. It captures a lot of detail for the scenery and the characters with the best animation available from Studio Ghilbi, and as well as maintaining the consistent quality of detail and colour, it makes use of some moments of top-notch three dimensional animation which is very visually pleasing. Playing of the two dimensional style of the standard Anime style, Hayao Miyazaki manages to use its two dimensional characters against the backdrop of many three dimensional effects and scenery in certain scenes which makes the strength of the animation in Spirited Away all the more effective. The immense colour in Spirited Away is exceptional and very vibrant, lighting up the screen and captivating the viewers.
And the dedication of the voice cast makes the entire experience more powerful, and it fuses with a strong musical score to ensure that Spirited Away is appealing from both a visual and auditory perspective. The musical score in Spirited Away made the entire experience more atmospheric as it kept the feeling up on the magnificent scale that the story had reached for while also enhancing the mysterious and intense nature of the story. The musical score maintains the same mystery as the film during its darker moments and optimism while it plays out its uplifting scenes, so it is constantly in tune with the mood of the story well.

So Spirited Away is definitely the greatest anime film I have ever seen because with Hayao Miyazaki's ambition and the hard work of Studio Ghibli, the film creates a lot of unforgettable imagery which makes the surreal tale of dark fantasy excellently animated and unforgettable for the magical effect it has on viewers.

Usually hit or miss for me, Hayo Miyazaki's whimsical imagining, Spirited Away is most definitely a hit. Each of the characters are fully realized and all have their own flair, from Chihiro to Noface to Yo Baba to the giant baby. All of the aspects of the film are good, but two are astonishing. One is the visual masterpiece put together, that includes everything the bright exuberant color palate to the effective use of camera making some really cool shots. The second was borderline oppressive in how much there was of it, and that's originality. Miyazaki weaves together such a never before conceived, wholly original world it was almost distracting from the story. This all being said, Spirited away is one of the best animation movies, and changed the way I see Miyazaki, 4.5/5

A movie called "Spirited Away" has been watched many people in the world. This is my favorite movie created by Hayao Miyazaki, who is one of the most respectable Japanese directors in the world.

The heroine of the story is a girl who is 10 years old, called Chihiro. The story moves with the process of her maturity. In the movie, there're meetings with various kinds of people and creatures that are recognized as "Japanese Gods" or those who were created by Miyazaki originally. Through life in strange world, Chihiro learns a lot of things which are needed to be an adult. This point is one of big themes of the movie. Miyazaki implies that people cannot avoid facing the independence from parents and entering to a society where they have not belonged when becoming an adult. Also, we can find a message that is related to destruction of nature. Hayao Miyazaki's Oscar winning animated film "Spirited Away" tells the story of a little girl who follows her parents into a strange amusement park and gets lost in the world of the spirits. Following the helpful young man, Haku, the young girl takes refuge in a bathhouse, run by a witch named Yubaba. In trying to free her parents from the spell that casts them into living, breathing livestock, and in trying to keep herself out of danger, she must brave the being known as No-Face, Yubaba's giant baby, and Yubaba's twin sister, Zeniba. The animation matches the quality of Miyazaki's previous work and contains a much more entrancing story that "Howl's Moving Castle". Miyazaki has a way with developing large amounts of characters in all his films, which makes them so entertaining to watch. He creates these fantasy worlds that are fully formed, with their own laws and rules, and then brings these worlds to life through the stories that are told in them, often filled with heroes and adventures, an unsuspected damsel in distress and evil ugly witches that can be conquered through friendship rather than destruction. "Spirited Away" is my favorite Miyazaki film yet, with "Howl's Moving Castle" being the only other film of his that I've seen, but already I enjoy the story-telling much more than I anticipated and even though I have zero affinity for anime, these films transcend that styling and create a genre of Japanese animation all its own.

The story doesn't amount as much to the magnificence of this movie as the animations and fantastical world do, and is a mere classical child narrative. The protagonist heroine gets in trouble because of a mistake, is brought into a prickly situation by an evil character, but the resilience of the good-natured heroine - and some good-natured helpers - win out over evil. The story is not bad, considering Spirited Away has a child audience, and even add enough nuance in its characters to make them more interesting than black-and-white stereotypes.

Let's say that you take a wrong turn into a tunnel that lands you into an abandoned town. Not to mention, your parents are turned into pigs. What would you do? Arguably one of Hayao Miyazaki's greatest movies, Spirited Away, tells the story of how a 10 year old girl goes on a quest to save her parents inside a mystical land many know as the spirit world. Despite being a Disney movie, Studio Ghibli worked hard to deviate from that restricting title and created a name all for itself.

Having seen a lot of Miyazaki's work, I can safely say that this is one of the best movies that he has ever created. I grew up watching Studio Ghibli films and have recently branched off into a lot more anime. While this movie was created early in his career as a film maker, it really sets the quality of his work at a high standard. It was his third well-known movie, after "Princess Mononoke" and "My Neighbor Totoro". After these successes, people started paying attention to his other films and realizing that they could find more of these magical worlds.

In the story, Chihiro, a little girl that just lost her parents to the spirit world, must fight to gain them back. She meets a friendly boy named Haku who helps her get a job at the place where the evil witch, Yubaba, keeps her workers and trespassers of the spirit world captive. She is the one that originally cursed her parents and the only person that can break the spell. However, this is no ordinary bathhouse. By day, it appears to be an abandoned building, but by night, it turns into a prestigious spa that is used by strange creatures from Japanese legends. No matter how friendly the face, Chihiro is terrified and cautious of them all.

Miyazaki does an amazing job of making his characters grow and mature, while making them strange enough but still well developed to create a magical world. Chihiro starts out as a bratty little kid who is too scared of facing anything in the real world, but when she is faced with life or death situations, she grows as a person and becomes more confident in herself. She discovers a new side of herself that allows her to gain courage and save her loved ones. Miyazaki creates hundreds of fantasy creatures, each serving a purpose in helping Chihiro grow, no matter how obscure. They are all given a place in this world he has created which helps shape this mystical land.

He also creates a fun story for all ages to enjoy. In no other movie will you find a bathhouse inside of a spirit world with a witch that steals your name to keep you prisoner and turns your parents into pigs. Neither will you find a river spirit that has forgotten his name, and can shift between a boy and a dragon. It is astounding how strange everything is, but how much sense it makes. It doesn't live by the classic Disney name, instead veering away from princesses, fairy tales, and "true love", but stories of growth and struggle.

Lastly, the film score in the movie was phenomenal. It was composed by Joe Hisaishi, a renowned artist that has written music for many of Miyazaki's films. He was the student of Takeo Watanabe, a legendary composer, and seems to have followed in his footsteps of greatness. All of the music for this movie, except for the last song, was played by the New Japan Philharmonic, a very prestigious ensemble. The pieces vary from soft and serene to action packed and lively. It showcases Hisaishi's work and brings together the entire movie. 

All in all, Miyazaki's movie is one for the ages that everyone should watch. The movie as a terrific plot with creative characters. The score is very imaginative and delightful to listen to, whether accompanied by the movie or not. "Spirited Away" teaches us lessons of finding ourselves, stepping out of our comfort zones, and helping those in need. It is a very inspiring movie and a work of art, one of the best I have ever seen.
