I don't hate anime! Seriously, I don't. And yet, the reputation this movie has suggests that anyone who doesn't hate anime will certainly love Spirited Away. Well that surely isn't the case. Many start their reviews of Spirited Away by saying how this was their first anime. This is not my first anime exposure, but it is my first Studio Ghibli, Hayao Miyazaki experience. And I was not pleased. 

I have found a great source of entertainment in anime TV shows. The street racing show, Initial D, is a wonderfully constructed human drama, with plenty of cars! It's not fair/possible to compare Spirited Away to the reality-based Initial D. Secondly would be the mind-blowingly great Cowboy Bebop. Don't be fooled by the name, the show is possibly the deepest piece of television I have ever seen. On the surface, Cowboy Bebop might just seem like a simple Sci-Fi/Western/Noir show, but it's so much more. Intellectually, Bebop puts Spirited Away to shame.

So what to take from these first two paragraphs? While this is my first Hayao Miyazaki movie, this certainly isn't my first introduction to anime. And I can say with confidence that I have seen much better in my very limited experience. 

The story centers around a young girl named Chihiro. On the day her family is moving into a new house (which means no friends and a scary new school for her); the family happens upon an abandoned theme park. Chihiro is apprehensive about exploring this park, but her parents insist. They wander the deserted stalls, until they come to one filled with delicious food. Her parents start gobbling it up ... like pigs. But Chihiro is still nervous; she walks away from her parents and runs into a boy named Haku. Haku warns Chihiro to get out of the park, before it's too late. But it already is too late. On returning to her parents, Chihiro finds them transformed into literal pigs! She is then thrown into an insane world, where she must find a way to transform her parents back, and get out of the nightmare.

Spirited Away appears to be the natural place for novices to start when it comes to Hayao Miyazaki. I was no exception. In some ways, I was very impressed. It takes an incredibly active imagination to come up with this world the movie lives in. So while I would call the movie a clear success in representing Miyazaki's imaginative filmmaking, I would also call it a jarringly poor example of storytelling. The movie is well over 2 hours long, and there really isn't enough story to support 90 minutes. The entire scene with the "stink spirit" is largely pointless and drawn out. The entire sup-plot with No-Face goes nowhere, and takes up a lot of screen time. There just isn't enough plot to merit a movie of this length. I honestly don't know why this movie is so well loved. It's just one random scene after another. Sure the world is interesting to behold, but that's about all the movie has to offer.

And yet it seems that anyone who doesn't like this movie has to wring their hands and fret over why they don't love "the great Miyazaki's magnum opus." Well I'm sorry to say it, but "the great Miyazaki" doesn't have a very good or very deep story on his hands with this one. The ending of the movie doesn't really explain enough, and leaves a few questions unanswered. Like why does everybody hate humans? What kind of creature is Lin, because she sure looks like a human to me? If Haku is a spirit, why does he take on the visage of a human boy? How does Chihiro even know that none of the pigs are her parents at the end? There are plot conveniences galore, thanks to the fact that the movie exists in a fantasy world. There are no ground rules, so anything goes. Whatever the plot requires can be conjured out of thin air. How convenient. These, along with a host of other questions, really grinded my gears. 

But let's be honest, if this movie wasn't so highly regarded, and if it wasn't made by the god-like Miyazaki, then none of these problems would even be an issue. But then again, if this movie wasn't so highly regarded, and if it wasn't made by the god-like Miyazaki, then I would have never watched it. 

The movie's calling card is its visuals. And those don't disappoint. I give Miyazaki all the credit in the world for dreaming up this universe. And then to translate that dream into a reality on screen is highly commendable. Visually, it's a piece of art. Though not exactly a piece of art I would actively seek out.

So yes, Spirited Away can be celebrated for its incredible world and inventive visuals. But it cannot be applauded for a quality story or great symbolism. Maybe I don't appreciate this movie as much because I just finished watching the afore mentioned anime series, Cowboy Bebop, less than a week ago. Honestly, Bebop is a piece of art that makes Spirited Away look like something created by a scared and confused child. Spirited Away doesn't do much dramatically. It doesn't have great symbolism (or maybe it had such deep symbolism, that it went right over my head), and it doesn't say anything about life on nearly the same level as Cowboy Bebop. Maybe it's not fair to compare the two ... then again, Spirited Away is considered one of the pinnacles of anime, so I don't think any comparison is off limits. Bebop is what really got me fascinated in anime, and it's one of the main reasons why I watched Spirited Away. Both are considered masterpieces within the genre, so I was expecting a lot out of Miyazaki's film. 

There isn't a whole lot to say about the vocal performances. All of them are perfectly acceptable. The girl who voices Chihiro in the English dub is a bit annoying at times, but overall there aren't any complaints regarding the performances.

The musical score by Joe Hisaishi is perfectly pleasant stuff, even if it does begin to blend into the woodwork in the middle portion of the movie. The opening title scene is very well scored with a beautiful piano theme. The only other time the score sticks out is in the scene where Haku and Chihiro are flying through the sky near the end of the movie. That was a show stopping piece of music that I will definitely seek out.

If this review comes off as me hating on the movie ... then I guess I got my point across. I'm sorry, but I didn't like this film. I actively disliked it. It just seems like one of those movies that you aren't allowed to hate, simply because everyone else loves it. In fact, for 20 minutes after I finished the movie, I tried to rationalize reasons to love this movie. I eventually gave up. I can see why some would like this movie ... even love it. But it certainly isn't for me. I'll give Miyazaki another shot with Princess Mononoke and Howl's Moving Castle. But I'll go into both of those movies with tempered expectations. Maybe I'm wrong about him, and I hope I am. Then again, if Spirited Away is the best Miyazaki has to offer...

Plot/Summary,Master animation director Hayao Miyazaki follows up on his record-breaking 1997 opus Princess Mononoke with this surreal Alice in Wonderland-like tale about a lost little girl. The film opens with ten-year-old Chihiro riding along during a family outing as her father races through remote country roads. When they come upon a blocked tunnel, her parents decide to have a look around -- even though Chihiro finds the place very creepy. When they pass through the tunnel, they discover an abandoned amusement park. As Chihiro's bad vibes continue, her parents discover an empty eatery that smells of fresh food. After her mother and father help themselves to some tasty purloined morsels, they turn into giant pigs. Chihiro understandably freaks out and flees. She learns that this very weird place, where all sorts of bizarre gods and monsters reside, is a holiday resort for the supernatural after their exhausting tour of duty in the human world. Soon after befriending a boy named Haku, Chihiro learns the rules of the land: one, she must work , as laziness of any kind is not tolerated; and two, she must take on the new moniker of Sen. If she forgets her real name, Haku tells her, then she will never be permitted to leave.

(****)  First some back story.  I've been trying to see this movie for years, but unfortunately I live in a college town.  Why does that matter?  Well, in Athens we have a great local chain of rental stores called Vision Video.  They are still thriving in the Netflix era because they have such a massive selection and are located in a town full of educated and, admittedly, hipster young folks.  This store is the source of most of my film-watching.  Every time I go, I browse through several movies I've been wanting to see and maybe some new releases, but I always make a point to see if Spirited Away is checked out.  For the last four years I've never seen it available, until a few days ago.  I finally got this DVD in my hands and went straight home to watch it, hoping my expectations weren't too high from all this waiting.  My friends, they weren't.

Spirited Away is the best piece of animation I've seen in a very long time.  After the first viewing, it has already made its way into my top five or so of all time.  That's saying something when you consider that favorite cartoons is probably the oldest list I ever came up with.  The Lion King still rests comfortably at the top, but this one is now in the ranks.  My first exposure to Miyazaki put me in a place I haven't been in since childhood, a fantasy world where things look strange and unfamiliar, and the rules don't necessarily make sense.  The level of creativity in this movie has been lost from American animation for a while.  We tend to just put an anthropomorphized animal into a conventional story line where all the characters and scenery are fairly recognizable.  The art of high fantasy has lately been restricted to novels or comics, with movies giving way to slapstick adventures of some brightly colored CGI character traveling through a brightly colored world trying to accomplish some goal which is secondary to the visuals and laughs.  The funny part?  This movie's visuals make CGI look like child's play.

Miyazaki is sort of a traditionalist in many ways, including his embrace of traditional Japanese culture.  HIs main accomplishment in this area is showing the power of hand-drawn animation.  There are some digital aspects to this film, but they are only used for certain effects, with the vast majority being drawn.  We need more of this today, because right now CGI just hasn't been able to reach the level of detail and intricacy that a real cartoon can.  I don't know enough about either to say why, but it's obvious in the results.  Cartoons can still make people look like people, rather than weird caricatured guys with giant heads and small bodies or the like.  Miyazaki adds another level of detail and realism which beats out most of the recent Disney animation.  One of my favorite scenes was when Chihiro was putting on a shoe and kind of struggled a little bit getting it over her heel.  I was happy to see this mentioned in the special features also, because it stuck out to me as an awesome attention to detail.

Right, so, plot.  The main character, a 10 year old girl named Chihiro, follows her parents through a suspicious tunnel and ends up in a spirit world.  She soon finds out that she is trapped, and has a long road and a lot of hard work between her and getting home again.  She becomes a cleaning lady at a bath house for the spirits (sort of a spa situation) and slowly transforms as a character from a whiny baby to a mature and determined heroine.  She works under the dictatorial owner of the house, Yubaba, who is sort of a wicked witch character with a soft side for her baby.  She also makes friends with a boy named Haku, but is never quite sure if she can trust him.  The movie unfolds in many unexpected directions as she continually tries to find some way to get back home while also treating those around her in a just and loving fashion.

The wise and touching values expressed in this movie absolutely floored me.  Hard work, independence, and care for your neighbors, friends, and even strangers are the primary themes.  I feel like this movie is much more responsible than most of what children in America are being taught today, sort of a "be an annoying brat and do whatever you want to" mentality that has spread through family comedies recently.  Spirited Away teaches about being willing to work for your goals, never giving up, but taking the time to stop and do the right thing on the way.  I could almost see Miyazaki and my grandfather sitting on the front porch discussing how people used to be in the good old days, when everyone worked hard and everyone loved one another.

Anyway this has stopped being a review and turned into a love-fest.  If you get a chance to see this film, please do.  It will restore your faith in animation and in humanity.  Also, it will make you feel like a kid again, and that's the best high in the world.

You want me to describe 'Spirited Away'? A few words spring to mind: freaky, weird, random, trippy. Read the film info for a proper story explanation but basically a girl enters a spiritual world and has to rescue her parents who have been turned into pigs. Sound interesting? Or does it sound freaky, weird, random and trippy? With all the top ratings it received, I figured it deserved a try. It gets full points for imagination and the soothing soundtrack compliments this fantasy world beautifully. However, it's bloody difficult to get into when all this random shizzle is going on. Children may have a good time since they can enjoy the animation and the wacky events this film throws at you, having less interest in deeper plot details. I had my own ideas about what this girl's adventure represented, which turned out to be wrong, but I thought it would have offered a satisfactory explanation (acknowledging the fact that what I predicted had already been done in 'Bridge to Terabithia'). Thanks to Wikipedia, you can research all the themes and running metaphors after which did a little to increase my appreciation of it. 

There is a shock factor from all the magical creatures and environment so the less you know beforehand, the happier you're going to be going into it. The data doesn't lie, 97% on rotten tomatoes suggests that my opinion is the odd-one-out but I believe most people I know personally would feel the same way. It's very much like your first lap dance; if you do take a chance on it then be prepared to come out feeling confused and unfulfilled.

Having co-founded Studio Ghibli in 1985 and directed 11 films himself, the highly unique animator Hayao Miyazaki has announced his retirement. The forthcoming "The Wind Rises" will be his last venture, so it now seems like a good time to look back at arguably his best film.
 Chihiro is a 10 year old girl who is moving to a new neighbourhood when her father decides to take a short cut and gets the family lost in an abandoned theme park. Helping themselves to food that's on display, Chihiro's parents are transformed into pigs and it soon becomes clear that they have stumbled into an alternate reality. Chihiro is then forced to find a way to free herself and her parents and find a way back to the human world.
 Quite simply, Miyazaki's "Spirited Away" is a triumphant, fantastical, masterclass. Not only is his hand drawn animation as gorgeously refined and refreshing as ever, but his storytelling incorporates everything from the mythical to the magical, taking us on a truly breathtaking visual and intelligent journey. As his later film "Ponyo" would channel the likes of Hans Christian Andersen's "The Little Mermaid", here, Miyazaki has undoubtedly crafted his version of Lewis Carroll's "Alice In Wonderland" and it's in this similar realm of imagination that he is able to flourish. We are introduced to a myriad of fantastical figures from Gods, Spirits and Witches to a Sea Dragon, an enormous baby and strange little coal miners, known as "Sootballs". Despite the rich hand drawn animation, though, it's not all played for fun. It's a rights-of-passage tale about the progression of a child to adulthood while finding the time to comment on the economic downturn of Japan and the increasing loss of it's culture to the western world. It's this very complexity that makes this Miyazaki's near masterpiece. The only issue with the film is that it's overlong, resulting in periodic disengagement - especially for younger viewers. It's runs just over the two hour mark and this is with several parts of the story cut out- the original version of Miyazaki's story would have run over the three hour mark. That being said, this is still one of animation's true classics and thoroughly deserving of it's Academy Award for Best Animated Feature in 2002.
 A breathtaking tour de force from one of the finest and most imaginative storytellers that animation has ever seen. Sadly, there will be only one more outing from Miyazaki but thankfully we've had to the pleasure to enter into his creative genius at all. Such accomplished cinematic experiences will be sadly missed.

It has become the film to rival all films in Japanese animation history, and since then has become one of the greatest pieces of work ever made in its original form. And without this film, it is likely to believe, that no one would ever hear of Hayao Miyazaki or Studio Ghibli or where these films were coming from if it weren't for this movie.

WHERE, DO I EVEN, BEGIN?

The plot starts with Chihiro and her parents moving into a new town and in a new home. While trying to get to their new house, they end up getting lost and coming across what seems to be an old abandoned theme park, until Chihiro is forcefully separated from her parents, while ghostly-like spirits start appearing out of nowhere, as a boy named Haku tells her that she is in the spirit world and that he can help her out of the spirit world as long as she obeys and does what the sorceress Yubaba tells her to do, and it's basically a story where Chihiro needs to be strong in order to rescue her parents and get back to the human world.

I can already tell you that I'm literally jealous of this film to the point of despising it, a sort of, "so good, it has to be bad", compliment, one of the highest compliments I could possibly more or less give a film. 
I'm jealous of its likable characters, I'm jealous of its original story, I'm jealous of its unbelievable animation and visuals, the music, the colors, everything in this movie is just PERFECT, FLAWLESS, INCREDIBLE AND PHENOMANAL. One of things especially the music, is one of my favorite musical scores that Joe Hisaishi has ever composed. 

The main thing I focus with this film is that it is nothing but imagination, creativity and above all else, originality, and I love every single second of it from start to the end credits, whether in English or Japanese, though personally I do like some things in English than I do the Japanese version, but that's beside the point, Miyazaki has done a phenomenal job bringing one of the best works ever to film history that it has become a groundbreaking point for people everywhere who has seen it. There are no problems, no interruptions, no annoying characters, it is a simply a beautiful masterpiece. It's fun, its creative, the kids will enjoy it, adults will enjoy it. I've gone on and on about it long enough, check it and decide for yourself.

"Spirited Away" tells the story of Chihiro, a 10-year-old girl whose parents are trapped as pigs in a world of spirits, gods, monsters, and witches. Chihiro joins the staff of a bathhouse, owned by a witch named Yubaba, until she can discover a way to transform her parents back into humans. It's a unique and enchanting story about true love, and the gorgeously drawn animation fills you with a sense of awe at its beauty. "Spirited Away" may prove too strange for some, due to some bizarre images, but it's a wonderfully imaginative movie for all ages.

A  magical film that more than earns it's title. Although the film has an almost childish innocence, it's not without its depth, and children and adults alike will feel themselves spirited away on a journey of mystical and magical wonder.
One of Spirited Away's best qualities is it's characters, every character, even it's minor characters, are memorable, lovable and full of life, and the character designs are very imaginative. some designs are a more innocent take on spirits and demons from traditional japanese folklore, often being somewhat wacky or unusual, but this only increases the appeal, as they are always full of personality. Even the antagonist, whilst still feeling dangerous to the main character, gives of an almost playful charm.
The plot remains interesting throughout, and isn't as simple or straight forward as many would expect from a "kids film",  and although the pacing feels a tiny bit slow at times, the vibrance of the film and liveliness of the characters more than make up for it. The film is beautifully animated, and the colourful setting never becomes a bore for the eyes. The dubbing on the English version is perfect, and feels perfectly in sync.

It's been a while since I saw the Academy Award winning film Spirited Away. Yes not only is it one of my favorite animated films, but it's also one of my favorite films of all time. I felt lucky to see this Miyazaki masterpiece with a charming story, wonderful animation and unforgettable characters. I loved every moment of Spirited Away that I felt that I could make a movie inspired by this film. The soundtrack in Spirited Away is unbelievable. The main theme starts out with a piano and then is taken over by the Japanese orchestra that right away gets me into a mood of watching the rest of the movie. Spirited Away not a typical animated musical comedy with funny sidekick characters to make the audience laugh with annoying jokes or a moment when the main character singing about his/ her feelings, But more like its own movie with its own story set in a Japanese bath house in the spirit world. When ever I tell someone  like my parents about Spirited Away, they tend to ignore the film or despise it. I don't understand why? Do they prefer CGI films instead with a used story or they only watch movies that are only made in America. Then a thought came in my head about why Miyazaki release this film in Japan. since Spirited Away was a huge hit in Japan, Miyazaki wanted the whole world to know about this film so they could learn more about the Japanese culture while watching this magnificent film. I think that's why Spirited Away is such a glorious film because it's educational to watch not just about the story or animation, but more one the world and culture that Miyazaki made towards the audience. Spirited Away is what I call a masterpiece in cinema because it's trying something different than the rest of the other usual American successful film. Spirited Away is a MUST see film for everyone of all ages.

Hayao Miyazaki is a genius filmmaker. His films create original stories, while being highly enjoyable, taking on politics and other topics. With Spirited Away, he creates something completely different.

The film follows a young girl known as Chihiro who enters a mysterious world with her parents. After her parents transform into pigs, Chihiro chooses to get a job at the bathhouse in order to save her parents. During this time, she changes, while also meeting different characters who are either kind or evil.

The artwork in this film is outstanding, with the creation of the bathhouse and the spirit world, as well as the different characters. The music, by Joe Hisaishi, is remarkable, supporting every character, especially Chihiro's change in character.

Miyazaki has crafted a terrific film, which is not only great for children, but also for adults as well.

I'd compare the way this film affected me to the way I feel when reading a particularly engrossing fictional novel. The way reading invokes imagery and emotion in one's mind is always considered to be far superior to when the stories are viewed on screen (thus leaving little to the imagination, since someone else is doing it for you). However... Spirited Away engrossed me from the beginning, and I know that if it was based on a literary counterpart written in the finest way imaginable, one could STILL not imagine how beautifully exquisite and perfect this story is. From the initial mystery regarding Chihiro's surroundings, to her struggle to navigate through the new and mystical world she finds herself in in  order to save her parents, and then, almost forgetting her main task in order to selflessly help Haku, with even Yubaba feeling regretful for having to test Chihiro in the end - Every aspect of this story is compelling and enchanting. Every emotion experienced by each character is masterfully imposed onto the viewer, but not forcefully, just naturally. 

A masterstroke of modern cinema.

Spirited Away is the first studio Ghibli film I've seen, and it's probably the most internationally known anime movie. It's from the highly acclaimed Miyazaki, but I must say I'm missing the hype. The animation is beautiful, and has many techniques I've never seen before. The pure atmospheric beauty of this film makes up most of my rating. I later encountered a set of stills from this, and it's like a two hour painting. So I will fully credit Spirited Away in its animation. The earliest flaw I noticed was the dialogue, the copy I had was the dubbed version, but the dialogue in it wasn't even on par with a Dreamworks movie. Those at least have social satire for the older crowds, here it was about on the level of a Disney channel cartoon. The screenplay felt set up purely for a kids crowd, which is why it shocks me how many adults have personally connected with this. The story is about a ten year old girl who stumbles into a world of creatures, and gets a job in a bathhouse for them. Some parts of what happened next felt like Miyazaki just BS'd as he went along. Went way to far into fantasy, and decided it can pull off any crap it made up. I strongly felt this when Haku learns his real name, which was a scene that frustrated me. While the story was not creative, the characters were. Miyazaki did have some lively ideas in the sense of character creation. The end of the line though is that I felt this was much more for kids, and while I can appreciate it, I believe it's over rated on a global scale.

A Coming of Age Story for all Ages
A Review by Calvin Joseph Kranig
At a time when 3D animation ruled the big screen with such films as Monster Inc. and Shrek, Spirited Away came as a shining beacon of why 2D animated were still relevant.   With Spirited Away Hayao Miyazaki(Director and Writer) and Studio Ghibli have created a masterpiece by which all future anime films will be measured against. It is a visual treat and an excellent example of 2D hand drawn animation at its finest. Hayao Miyazaki creates a breathtakingly imaginative new world that only helps immerse the viewer into the plot of the film. The story is a classic coming of age story, and invokes memories of Alice in Wonderland. It is a terrific film for the whole family to enjoy, and is an excellent introduction into the anime genre. 
The movie begins with a ten year old girl, Chihiro(voiced by Daveigh Chase), and her mother(Lauren Holly) and father(Michael Chiklis) driving to their new home. Along the way the father  decides to take a short cut on a dilapidated old path which leads the family to an old abandoned theme park and they begin to roam through the streets while Chihiro begs for them to go back. Chihiro's constant whining at the beginning of the story can become quite annoying, and for some, this might ruin the movie right from the start.
It is there for a very good reason however in that it sets up Chihiro's character as that of any ten year old girl. If she was perfect from the start there would be nothing to build upon; there would be no way for her character to grow. Chihiro's whining to return to the car might be annoying but it turns out to be good advice as Chihiro's parents find a food stand and begin to quickly devour the food that mysteriously is still there. Chihiro walks away towards a bath house and runs into a boy by the name of Haku(Jason Marsden) who yells at her to return across a stream that she and her family had crossed to get to the theme park. As Chihiro runs back she runs into her parents who are now... Giant Pigs! Chihiro whines in terror(once again), and runs back to the stream to find its been turned into an ocean. The movie really start to pick up here as a boat comes across full of spirits. Chihiro runs back through the park, and finds that it is also full of spirits.
She runs into Haku who begins to help her get her bearings in this new fantastical world. He helps her get a job at the bathhouse from the evil witch Yubaba(Suzanne Pleshette) , but it comes at the cost of her name which she is forced to change to Sen. It is this beggining to the movie that begins to draw comparisons to Alice in Wonderland.
It is in essence the same story. A little girl is dropped into a strange world full of strange creatures and must find a way to get out. However, this is where the comparison ends, because unlike Alice in Wonderland, Spirited Away has an actual storyline and is not just a collection of wacky scenes. In Spirited Away the main protagonist develops into a new character as the story progresses, and faces the constant conflict of having to savee her parents throughout the movie. This gives the story direction which is something that is not present in Alice in Wonderland, and therefore makes Spirited Away the superior film. The beggining of the two movies might be similar, but the the rest of Spirited Away couldn't be more different than Alice in Wonderland.   
The beginning Spirited Away quickly segways into the middle part of the film which consists of a bunch of character developing scenes that showcase the good, non-whining, side of Chihiro as she toils away in the bathhouse.. These all lead up to the big finale where Chihiro is forced to save her parents. 
Along the way Chihiro's character grows into a perfect role model for any ten year old girl. She showcases her altruism, and goes from being a self centered whining little girl to being a caring individual. It is a beautiful story that ranks up there with the best coming of age stories out there. 
The movie also succeeds in hurdling a major trap that most Japanese animated films fall into, and that is the disastrous occurrence of a poor japanese to english dub. The characters mouths match what they are saying a majority of the time, and there are few instances where you sit there wondering if your watching a Godzilla movie. The great dubbing of the film into english does not add much to the film, but it more importantly does not detract from it either. 
Spirited Away is an instant classic, and everyone should watch it at least once in their lifetime. It showcases a beautiful coming of age story that teaches children the benefits of altruism. It has memorable characters and scenes, and above all, it is a perfect example of the beauty of 2D animation.

Headed by legendary Studio Ghibli, Spirited Away, was released on July 20th, 2001 by director Hayao Miyazaki.

The highest grossing film in Japanese history is a story about a ten year old girl, Chihiro, and her entrance into an intransigent and unknown world. 
This film is compelling because of its direction and writing front and foremost. Spirited Away utilizes the greatest asset the medium has to offer in the art direction; it's not trying to look like reality, it's letting us explore a new world so much unlike our own.

The images on screen, rich with symbols and metaphors tell the audience so much about this place without a word. Miyazaki's directing makes the protagonist feel like an extension of the viewer, the point of view camera angles emphasizes the urgency Chihiro feels in this new frightening environment and the dark tones in the beginning really lead to a genuine feeling of being alone and scared while remaining highly intrigued.

Every scene interjects yet another level of mysticism, just as more answers are revealed more questions follow. The balance that Miyazaki walks is so perfectly crafted, you can rest assured from the introduction to the film that you are in for a well-paced ride.

The consistency of the characters throughout allows your own perspective to change; the landmark achievement of this film is taking your interpretation of a frightening and serious world into a warm and inviting home. The writing is so brilliantly masked by the "Pixar" like charm; that questions about your own identity will still linger far after the closing credits.

On top of that each character has a fulfilling arc to add, and the honest emotional ties formed with these animated characters are such a propitious surprise. Sounds and animation was the bulk of communication for the first thirty minutes and it created such a personalized tone open for interpretation for any viewer.



However, the mystery and intrigue of the world unfortunately met a climax far before the actual plot did. Around the hour and fifteen minute mark the film lost a great deal of surprises; I liked the world but it was nowhere near as compelling.

This could be overlooked but the actual conclusion to the plot which was absolutely terrible! For all the intelligent symbols and extended metaphor in the rising action to cop out at the end with a deus ex machina ending of true love between two ten year olds being the catalyst to save everyone brings such a clash of shallow writing to the otherwise insightful and meditative first two thirds of the script.

With that being said, Spirited Away is a sincere achievement in animation. Using the advantages of the medium, thought provoking writing, and awe-inspiring art direction; Spirited Away is a timeless film that shouldn't be over looked.

Prepare yourself for a magical journey in SPIRITED AWAY, the acclaimed Japanese animation by renown director Hayao Miyazaki. Chihiro finds herself lost in the spirit world after her parents are transformed into pigs by a malevolent witch, and she must gather her strength and courage if she hopes to save them! SPIRITED AWAY transports us to a fantasy world that is filled with strange and magnificent creatures who are brought to life through Miyazaki's captivating animated style. Chihiro's journey is a timeless story of self-discovery and the coming of age, where a young girl first discovers love and compassion by acting outside herself. Miyazaki uses traditional storytelling techniques to paint a unique new fairy tale that children of all ages can relate to, while keeping with its Japanese origins. The sometimes horrifying creatures that Chihiro encounters each represent a stage of childhood that she must overcome, and bring with them valuable lessons that she will use in her budding adolescence. SPIRITED AWAY provides childlike wonder for kids and adults alike, and is a masterpiece of modern animation. 

-Carl Manes

I try not to give all the films I "like" a 10/10 because two films I like, per se, might not be on the same level; not all films I like are 10/10 movies.. Therefore I try to give films an honest rating, there are only a few of my favorite movies that are 10/10 movies, those being, for example, the lord of the rings films, the green mile, and a few others, Spirited Away is one of them as well. I think I was maybe 10 or 11 years old when Spirited Away popped up on cartoon network, I caught maybe the second half of it but I was enthralled so (get this, so old fashioned) I grabbed the newspaper and looked through the TV schedule to find the next viewing. I ended up watching it every time it was on TV until they stopped showing after like two weeks, my dad thought it was unhealthy for me and encouraged me to go outside anyway. I ended up forgetting about the movie for a long time, and I mean a long time. As a grew up I kinda picked up bird watching as a hobby and am actually now turning it into a profession, but I remember doing some research on barn owls and watching a video where the top rated comment was "barn owls always remind me of no-face from spirited away" holy crap, I've heard of that movie, yeah, it was that one on TV years ago, gosh I need to watch that again. I got my hands on the movie and as I sat down to watch it, for the first time in like 9 years, I thought to myself, "hmmmm... I hope this movie still appeals to me now that I'm almost 20" two hours later, there's me wiping tears from my eyes, grabbing my computer and looking up every other ghibli film out there. It was like I was immediately addicted, I needed my fix of ghibli films so I, eventually, over a year or so, got my hands on all of them; honesty, most of them are quite fantastic as well, especially mononoke and totoro. But back to this movie; as someone who watched dragon ball z and digimon and pokemon and anime like that and eventually grew out of it, I was completely astounded at how 'real' this film felt. No, obviously, the things that happened in the film took place in a fantasy world that was expertly crafted and just stretched the imagination beyond belief, but the characters felt real, they were tangible and believable, I connected with them and I cared about them because their emotions were earnest and connected with me so vividly. The character development was fantastic and that was one of the things that made it such a joy to watch. And some people might say that the story is haphazard and confusing; I didn't think so, I think the things that were unexplained in the films or ambiguous were meant to be that way, it adds to the mystery of it, and that's another that I loved so much; being able to make those decisions for yourself as to what you believe the writers implied. Not only that, but the animation itself was absolutely fantastic! The most visually breathtaking drawings and scenes I've ever seen are from this movie. And, as a musician and student of music, I'd like to say that Joe Hisaishi absolutely perfected this film with his impeccable score! Since I first re-watched it almost a year ago, I've probably watched it 5 or 6 times since and I just cant get enough of it. I listen to the soundtrack all the time and it's just beyond beautiful, as I mentioned before. This film is an absolute treasure, many people write off animated films before they give them a chance, but this is a film that could easily be translated into a live action film with real actors and it would work just as well; the medium with which a film is presented doesn't always dictate the quality or style of the film. I never thought that an anime film would be one of my favorite films of all time but indeed it is, I will watch Spirited Away a hundred more times, and when I have kids, I'll make sure it's one of the first films they watch as well.

Miyazaki's "Spirited Away" is an imaginative, magical, and astonishing animated film. The story is always unique and the visuals are always stunning. The movie drags in a few spots since it is pretty lengthy for an animated movie but for the most part the movie leaves you in wonder and delight. Its a top notch animated movie that is definitely worth a watch.

Never saw this award winning anime when it graced the theatres in its hallucinatory way and was pronounced Best Animated Feature Film at the Oscars back in 2003 [beating, among others, ICE AGE and LILO & STITCH] but now I can understand how something so unusually foreign to a North American audience can hold such a spell compared to the predictable mainstream fare.  In SPIRITED AWAY humans are secondary to an imaginative world of creepy supernatural beings shaped in the bizarre forms of  monsters of all sorts.  Chirhiro, the spunky little heroine, and only human, at the centre of SPIRITED AWAY must confront these strange lifeforms, otherworldly spirits, in order to save her parents who have both turned into giant pigs.  Will she manage?  Two hours of supernatural Japanese artwork reveals both the lessons learned and consequences that  are the result of walking through unknown, perhaps even forbidden land, in Japan's eerie take on Alice In Wonderland. Very creative and spooky.
Un clasico instantaneo de la animacion que demuestra la maestria del director Hayao Miyazaki.  Ninos, jovenes y adultos se deleitaran con la travesia de la joven Chihiro.

Perhaps master Miyazaki's definitive film. This is the perfect marriage of Miyazaki's ambitious imagination and gentle storytelling. You can admire it for hours, but you'll much rather hold it in your heart for a lifetime.

A true classic in my eyes, "Spirited Away" is definitely one of my favorite animated movies of all time. This film is visually stunning, and the conflict is extremely gripping. The character's are perfect, every person big or small really makes the story better. The effects and the sounds make everything more crazy and dramatic. And as a bonus, the dubbing is great. This is a movie you can't miss.

I'll give this 5 STARS!!! This was a VERY impressive Anime movie. 97% of the critics and 95% of the audience liked it!

Hayao Miyazaki's animated storytelling is so much better than just about anything that comes out of Hollywood. They should be taking notes. Seriously. This may be his best ever, as the tale about a pre-teen girl's bizarre separation from her parents and her servitude in the strangest bathhouse you'll ever see. While she looks for a way to be reunited with them, her life is filled with exotic characters of a certain depth. Tossing out provocative imagery like candy at a parade, there's something wrong with you if you don't like this.

Bizarre, but entertaining.  The episodic story arc works because you can almost immediately like the protagonist and enjoy watching her grow throughout the film.  The drawings are also quite a bit of fun (if you go in for that sort of thing).

The most unique, compelling, beautiful, enchanting, exciting, breathtaking, masterful, and downright amazing movie I have seen in a LONG time. Go get this movie, right now.

A faerie tale for adults as well as children, this classic fantasy by Hayao Miyazaki combines Eastern and Western mythology with modern storytelling. This film is one of his crowning achievements as an animator and storyteller, and in the years to come will no doubt be considered one of the best animated films of all time.
Well worth watching, and required viewing for any animation fans.

Magical, insightful, and nicely contained within a fully realized world, Spirited Away is not only a fantastic fantasy adventure but also a heartfelt story full of lessons about the wisdom of children, greed, and treatment of our environment. Though albeit a bit strange and coming to a crashing halt as an ending, Spirited Away is still a sweet film, also with a killer score.
